comments.commentBody:
Trump is doing well with 22% of 46% of the country - or 10% of the country.

Most voters are embarrassed by Trump. Those who aren't simply don't know any better.

Archie Bunker of Queens is running for office as Donald Trump of Queens.

Undocumented workers came into this country just like the vast majority of immigrants in the 19th and 20th century did.

Anyone who has worked with an immigrant to the US knows they work much harder because they have to. They sacrifice for future generations, value education and contribute much to the economy.

The Queens bigot Trump finds it easy to categorize a large group of people as rapists and criminals because he is an ill-informed bigot.

All those fools who think he will be a great President should consider he bankrupted 4 companies and was sued for running a fraudulent for-profit university that left students with nothing but piles of debt.

He knows nothing of foreign policy, fiscal and monetary policy, international affairs, trade, finance, or administration.

Trump is a con man and a huckster proving their is a sucker born every minute.

"The more common phrase, ‘‘illegal immigrant,’’ also implies suspicion, but strip the noun from it and the entire identity of a person who crosses the border without permission, or outstays his or her visa, is reduced to that of a criminal: What rights could he or she be entitled to?"

Wouldn't someone in the country illegally be a criminal?

"This debate will go on for as long as people fail to understand that the term "illegal" is imprecise in that it fails to distinguish between violations of criminal and civil law."
Whether it's a criminal or civil violation the term "illegal" is correct.

"Also, as long as people think that every single "illegal immigrant" is a person who entered without inspection, as the comments below seem to assume,"
Seems like you are the one making the assumptions.

" there will be little enlightening discussion on the subject. "
You have provided proof enough of that.

Dear Reverend Bates,
The illegal immigrants have had the opportunity of experiencing life in the U.S. Now they can go home to demand that their own governments end corruption, improve education, and open up their economies to the extent that they have experienced here. This would really enhance life in Mexico and in the Central American countries.

Everyone understands that "illegal immigrant" describes the status of the person's status residency; no one thinks it means that the person is illegal, as that doesn't even make sense. Does "poor public speaker" mean that the person is poor? Does "good writer" mean that the person is good?

The drive to call use the word "undocumented" doesn't arise from any confusion about the meaning of illegal; it is a deliberate effort to suggest that the violation is nothing more than a technicality. It is disingenuous and I think dishonest.
if it's a felony, they are

Illegal aliens are illegal, but they are not felons just because they break the law to come here. That point should never be lost sight of.

The term illegal does not deny humanity. The premise that we are as responsible for connotations as for denotations reflects the relativization of making abortion legal, but still believing we have the right to define ourselves as not guilty of facilitating and even enshrining murder. We make it a condition of a young girl's freedom. It is her choice, but the fact we let the law allow it says more than our empty personal professions about what we do or do not value.

There really has been a philosophical shift in this country, and this equating of connotations with denotations is de-educating us about the rule of law that has seemed to work in a peculiar way in the US and Western culture at least for a little while, for whatever reason.

Thank you for your service! I personally want to Thank You for everything you have done for your country.

Vietnam Veteran
Spot on.
Welcome to the US.  And I bet your family did not receive free food, free housing, free health care, free education, free child care.

Our family came to this country legally on a visa in 1964 when I was 10. I remembered vividly that every January we followed the law and went to the Post Office to fill out an Alien Registration Card until we became Naturalized American Citizens. We thought nothing of being categorized as Aliens and did not feel discriminated against because we can accept that non-Citizens do not have the same rights and privileges as Citizens. That was why we pursued obtaining our Citizenship.

After getting my Citizenship, I joined the Army and earned a Purple Heart to give back to this Nation that gave me so much.

As far as our family knew, if anyone came into this Country without a visa or overstayed their visa, they are breaking the law and are illegal. To this day, I still believe illegal is the proper term to use and it does not disturb me that they do not have the same rights and privileges that our family had worked so hard to gain.

Uh, the ACA according to the Congressional Budget Office reduces the deficit. It has slowed the rise in healthcare costs.  The number of uninsured in the country is at record lows.  Pre-existing conditions no longer mean you cant get insurance.  No caps on coverage.  No cancellations.  Undocumented immigrants cannot sign up for insurance on the exchanges.  The horrors, the horrors.
for the 100th time , illegals are NOT on the healthcare system

Yes, but those are "all the rules" that stifle invention. Without "all the rules", health insurers can become Silicon Valley-like innovators, much like they apparently were before Obamacare opened the market to sick people. Insurers will once again be free to implement such innovations as fine print in complex plans designed to not pay off when needed. And it will never rain until after sundown, either.
100  trillion in debt for entitlements, who is going to pay for the millions of illegals on the healthcare system?
Of course.  This is supposed to be news?  These men are in the pocket of wealthy big-money interests, and would eliminate all aid for the poor if they could.

Walker truly believes in a gifted class which he belongs to and the serfs.  He is doomed to failure at every turn.  He really is myopic, a real puppet of the wealty , and thoroughly corrupt at every real and intellectual level.  He is not alone among the candidates!
In other words their plans are useless for everyone but health insurers.

Every person 50 to 64 would be given $3,000 to spend on health insurance, while everyone 18 to 34 would get $1,200

__

$3000 will NOT buy squat for someone over 60.

Plan with a $5000 deductible per person and 30% copays (and no drug coverage) was going for $9000 a year for 1 person in this state pre-ACA

Humans are rear-gut fermenters - which means if they eat raw meat it rots in their intestines and causes illness and disease. True omnivores, like dogs, can eat rotting carrion with no ill effects.  Humans do not have incisors and canines or claws to tear apart flesh. To say animals are not sentient is against any intelligent person's clear observations that they cry when separated from loved ones or when in pain and they show joy when happy.  To believe otherwise is simply foolish.
RIBBIT
Thank you- I thought the addition of olive oil very strange in this recipe. I think I'll just stick to canola and sesame oils.

NYT is merely providing readers with an option they think tastes good and they're probably doing it for the very reason that some people would never think to change up a Chinese-inspired recipe in that way.

Please, if you are going to use evoo, call it "Chinese inspired or influenced ..." Instead, use any flavorless vegetable oil such as plain olive oil or, better yet, peanut oil.

No Chinese dish comes to mind utilizes the flavor of olives.

Vouchers, tax credits, etc., have been analyzed to death and it is clear they result in higher costs, or fewer insured people, or both.

These plans have no serious merit behind them. They are purely ideologically driven.

At heart, the calculation is simple and cynical: keep it the same for the core target GOP voters - older white people many/most of whom are already retired, and slash it for everyone else.

Sigh. Yes, single payer is better, cheaper, etc.

It would have required 60 votes in the Senate and 218 in the House. On which planet did this exist in 2010? None. On what planet is it likely to exist any time soon? None.

Joe Lieberman would not have turned his back on the health insurance industry, which bought his entire political career, no matter how many times President Obama invited him over for a beverage and some golf. Never mind Ben Nelson and a slew of Democrats who were only barely convinced to vote for the most progressive option available (the ACA). It was the ACA or nothing -- and nothing would have meant health care costs continuing to spiral upwards at a rate faster than they are now and the continuance of the health insurance industry raking in record profits quarter after quarter while tens of thousands of Americans died because they had no insurance or were booted off the insurance they had because, well, they used it.

The ACA is far from a thing of beauty and elegance, but it was and remains the best option available. Forward motion is better than the backward steps we'd been taking for nearly a century.

Well, $3k will buy me, maybe, 3 mos. of health insurance. Not cover any bills mind you, that's another $7-$10k away before that part kicks in. (And I'm not even looking to be subsidized, just stating what the market costs currently are for someone not on the exchange.)
I am looking for, and now, again, am concerned about is access, however. I am no fan of ACA -- should have been single payer, or not at all -- but now that we've all been 'outed' in terms of pre-existing conditions, should ACA go away, what to do for so many during the gap years between now and 65?
Walker, who by virtue of his lifelong government positions, has fantastic insurance for himself, and his wife, who is a diabetic, really is out of touch with the realities of the self-insured.
I could really get hooked on listening to Maxwell curse his carrier and the veterinarian.
Wow! People 18-34 would give $1,200 whole dollars a year for health insurance.  What are these people smoking?

Let's not forget Walker is a mere shill for his rich handlers, so his plan makes it ever clearer "what rich people want," with a political calculation nodding in the direction of the aged.  Truly awful stuff.

I am struck by a measure of desperation on the part of Gov. Walker and Sen. Rubio in throwing out ACA-replacement proposals that were clearly not well thought-out. They seem to be responding to the criticism that the GOP only wants to repeal the ACA, but not replace it with something merit worthy. It seems clear that they farmed these proposals out to their staffs, who came up short in terms of homework and analysis.

If I recall, both Senators Rubio and Cruz noted long ago that the ACA, once in place and firmly rooted, would flourish and become virtually (politically) impossible to uproot.

Nick,

The Navy that has really confusing insignia for officers is the Russian Navy. There are four different sizes of stars and the Fleet ADMIRAL with the single largest star outranks the three-STAR ADMIRAL with high medium-sized STARs, who in turn outranks the Captain Lieutenant with four small stars. You can see STARs here:

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Naval_ranks_and_insignia_of_the_Russian_Fe...

I think Washington did nothing wrong, and glad to see the whining bad losers from Iowa ended up getting eliminated too.  If you don't like what Washington did, don't get yourself in the position of expecting them to help you.

The kids are the ones who really loose .Thanks coaches...They worked very hard to get to the position they were in ,,just to  loose out because of unsportsman like conduct ...they  will never forget this e negative part of their life
In a word. YES. FIFA has been operating under a cover of darkness for way too long.

Really? Learning that FIFA is corrupt is on par with Captain Renault being shocked there's gambling going on at Rick Cafe Americain. Nobody is talking FIFA on the streets or in the bars and quite frankly most people don't care.

Go to places like Legends, Nevada Smith's, Ryan's Daughter, etc and the talk is all NYCFC & Red Bulls.

@ Egbert Souse, Manhattan
Well, nobody (least of all, myself) ever said that corruption is something NEW with FIFA -- But I am firmly of the opinion there is nothing wrong with keeping informed about just how insanely corrupt that organization is.
That said. I am very pleased that Americans and New Yorkers are continuing to find a deep and abiding love for the sport.

And yes. I am familiar with all of the pubs that you have mentioned. However as a DFB fan, I tend to frequent other locales where people tend to discuss FIFA as much as they discuss the game.
In the meantime, Good Luck NYCFC !! -- and I hope that Frank Lampard can finally get back on the pitch....soon.

Sure would like to see a NY Times article headline featuring MLS. You've got several articles on Prem, some on other Euro leagues, some on the USWNT--all of which is fine, but you have diddly on our vibrant domestic leagues, particularly MLS. Of the three up-and-coming national leagues around the world--MLS, J-League, and A-League--it is MLS that is growing the fastest and has the greatest potential. Give it some coverage, for goodness sakes!
